extraction_metadata.article_title: Clarifying the Value Elements of Business Models for Disturbance Management in Supply Chains

extracted_data.question_text: What is the name and definition of the software business model presented in the article?
extracted_data.extracted_value: SaaS-based disturbance management and analysis solution for supply chains. A database-based service solution that aims to provide a tool for companies to analyze and manage transport disturbances, and thus provide companies an opportunity to develop proactive risk management.
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 3: 'The new service is a database-based service solution that aims to provide a tool for companies to analyze and manage transport disturbances, and thus provide companies an opportunity to develop proactive risk management. The solution is planned to work with Software as a Service (SaaS) principles (used and delivered through internet technology)'

extracted_data.question_text: What synonyms or alternative terms are used in the article to refer to this software business model?
extracted_value: SaaS based service entity
Software as a Service principles
cloud-based service
database-based service solution
disturbance management and analysis solution
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 3: 'The solution is planned to work with Software as a Service (SaaS) principles' | Page 5: 'SaaS based service entity' | Page 3: 'database-based service solution'

extracted_data.question_text: What is the main vertical segment or industry where the software business model presented in the article is applied?
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1: 'The aim of the study is to clarify the value elements of a business model for disturbance management and analysis in supply chains' | Page 3: 'logistic-intensive companies'

extracted_data.question_text: What is the target customer type of the software business model presented in the article?
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 3: 'Our research takes the perspective of a solution provider developing a service entity to logistic intensive companies' | Page 4: 'three different types of customer segments for the new service for the management and analysis of transport disturbances can be identified; 1) Owners of the cargo (low value of transported goods), 2) Owners of the cargo (high value of transported goods) and 3) logistic operators'

extracted_data.question_text: What is the typical size of offering companies that adopt this software business model as described in the article?
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 3: 'Our research takes the perspective of a solution provider, a company Alfa, which develops and offers a service entity to logistic-intensive companies. The service is new and the company does not yet have a specific business model related to the service'

extracted_data.question_text: In which geographic region was the software business model presented in the article studied or applied?
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 3: 'The data of customer needs for the study was gathered by conducting semi-structured interviews in 14 logistic-intensive companies all around Finland'

extracted_data.question_text: What specific customer segment is most detailed in the article regarding the software business model?
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 4: '3) Logistic operators Among logistic operators the need for management and analysis of transport problems is already identified, and it is an important part of companies' operations. In the logistic industry the companies search for competitive advantage especially with cost-effectiveness and quality, and thus the disturbance management is seen as a consequential action'

extracted_data.question_text: Which actors participate in the ecosystem of the software business model presented in the article and how do they interact?
extracted_value: Company Alfa | Solution provider | Develops and offers service entity | Provides disturbance management solution
Cargo owners | Customers | Use service for transport disturbance analysis | Interact with logistic operators
Logistic operators | Customers | Use service for competitive advantage | Serve cargo owners
Transport companies | Stakeholders | Subject of disturbance analysis | Compensate for disturbances
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 3: 'Our research takes the perspective of a solution provider, a company Alfa, which develops and offers a service entity to logistic-intensive companies' | Page 4: 'three different types of customer segments for the new service for the management and analysis of transport disturbances can be identified; 1) Owners of the cargo (low value of transported goods), 2) Owners of the cargo (high value of transported goods) and 3) logistic operators' | Page 4: 'Usually disturbances, caused by transport companies are compensated by transport companies (liability of the carrier)'

extracted_data.question_text: What motivations lead to the adoption of the software business model presented in the article?
extracted_value: Need for information about transport disturbances and their costs
Minimizing high costs of quality
Systematic compilation of statistics on disturbances
Transparent reporting of disturbances
Comprehensive analysis of disturbance causes
Centralized systems for following company's situation
Improving operational efficiency and cost savings
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 4: 'According to our study, the customer needs related to the analysis and management of disturbances vary between different industries' | Page 4: 'The results of the study show that there are clear needs for the development of solutions for disturbance management and analysis in supply chains' | Page 4: 'Need for information about the success of total transportations; what kind of disturbances happen and what are their costs'

extracted_data.question_text: What factors contribute to the success of the software business model as described in the article?
extracted_value: Cost and time savings → Increased operational efficiency
Customer satisfaction and reputation → Enhanced company reputation
Prevention of disturbances → Reduced number of disturbances
Transparent reporting → Better stakeholder relationships
Comprehensive analysis → Better decision making
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 4: 'The transparent systems for disturbance management and analysis could e.g. enhance the reputation of a company, make operations more fluent, increase quality, create customer satisfaction, help to avoid disappointed customers, create competitive advantage, and enable information to be available anytime and for those who need it' | Page 4: 'Increased operational efficiency and costs saving are seen both as benefits and also as prerequisites for the management system in all customer segments'

extracted_data.question_text: What prerequisites or conditions are necessary for the software business model as described in the article?
extracted_value: Internet technology access → SaaS delivery model
Systematic information collection → Database-based service
Customer awareness of disturbances → Market demand
Compatibility with ERP systems → Integration requirements
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 3: 'The solution is planned to work with Software as a Service (SaaS) principles (used and delivered through internet technology)' | Page 3: 'The basic principle behind the service is to collect systemically information about customer's transport disturbances to the information system' | Page 4: 'Need for systems that are compatible with the ERP-systems of a company'

extracted_data.question_text: What restrictions or incompatibilities are mentioned in the article about the software business model?
extracted_value: Competition with companies' own ERP systems → Market positioning challenges
Low awareness in some industries → Limited market penetration
Different industry characteristics → Need for segment-specific solutions
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 5: 'The Competition in this kind of SaaS based service solutions was found to be rather low, although companies' own ERP systems and other applications are competing with the new solution of the company Alfa' | Page 4: 'The research shows that in these industries the need for management and analysis of disturbances is at the moment relatively small, but when the awareness of disturbances increases, also these industries are interested to develop their operations'

extracted_data.question_text: What challenges are identified in implementing the software business model as presented in the article?
extracted_value: Competition with existing ERP systems
Low awareness of disturbance management needs in some industries
Different customer segment requirements
Need for quantitative estimations of cost structure and revenue streams
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 5: 'The Competition in this kind of SaaS based service solutions was found to be rather low, although companies' own ERP systems and other applications are competing with the new solution of the company Alfa' | Page 5: 'Further research is needed in creating SaaS based business models for disturbance management. Especially, the quantitative estimations about cost structure and revenue streams are required'

extracted_data.question_text: What practices are used to mitigate challenges of the software business model as described in the article?
extracted_value: Customer needs analysis → Understanding market requirements
Segment-specific value propositions → Addressing different customer types
SaaS characteristics (low price, high volume) → Competitive positioning
Comprehensive benefit communication → Market education
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 3: 'The customer needs were collected by conducting semi-structured interviews in 14 companies' | Page 5: 'The value proposition will vary depending on the customer segment and their products to which the new solution will be provided' | Page 3: 'Also other SaaS business characteristics (e.g. easy to deploy and deliver, online purchase and support, low price, high volume, common business processes, transferrable risk, and low budgetary expense) have an influence on the development of a business model'

extracted_data.question_text: What future trends or evolutions are mentioned in the article about the software business model?
extracted_value: Need for quantitative estimations of cost structure and revenue streams
Further research in creating SaaS based business models for disturbance management
Development of comprehensive business models beyond technology orientation
